row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 4.9 percent after increasing 3.8 percent in the second quarter. Exports, consumer spending, and inventory investment all accelerated. Corporate profits turned down.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade for the Third Quarter of 2007
row.Description: These statistics, including the estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: Errata: U.S. Benchmark Input-Output Accounts, 2002
row.Description: Various tables that were published in the October 2007 Survey have been revised: the make and use of commodities before redefinitions, the list of industries in the 2002 benchmark accounts, and the input-output commodity composition of NIPA personal consumption expenditure categories.

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: Third Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Douglas B. Weinberg, Jessica Melton Hanson, Kristy L. Howell
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit decreased $10.5 billion to $178.5 billion from $188.9 billion in the second quarter; the surpluses on income and services increased, while the deficit on goods decreased.

row.Title: An Ownership-Based Framework of the U.S. Current Account, 1997â€“2006
row.Author: Jeffrey H. Lowe
row.Description: This annual supplement to the international transactions accounts presents current-account statistics that combine cross-border trade and net receipts of affiliates from sales by multinational companies.

row.Title: State Personal Income: Third Quarter of 2007
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income growth for the nation accelerated, increasing 1.4 percent after increasing 0.9 percent. State personal income growth ranged from 0.8 percent to 3.6 percent. Growth accelerated or held steady in all but 11 states.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP grew 0.6 percent after growing 4.9 percent in the third quarter. Inventory investment turned down, while exports, consumer spending, and federal government decelerated. In 2007, real GDP increased 2.2 percent after increasing 2.9 percent in 2006.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Employee Stock Options and the National Economic Accounts
row.Author: Carol E. Moylan
row.Description: Stock options have become common as part of employee pay packages. This BEA Briefing discusses the national economic accounts' treatment of these options and plans for improvements.

row.Title: The Reliability of the GDP and GDI Estimates
row.Author: Dennis J. Fixler, Bruce T. Grimm
row.Description: This analysis confirms that BEA's estimates provide an accurate picture of the economy, indicating among other things whether growth was positive or negative and whether it was accelerating or decelerating.
row.Category: National, Gross domestic product and gross domestic income

row.Title: Annual Industry Accounts: Revised Statistics for 2004â€“2006
row.Author: Robert J. McCahill, Kevin B. Barefoot, Robert J. Corea
row.Description: The services sector once again powered economic growth in 2006. Finance and insurance industries accounted for about 25 percent of economic growth; professional, scientific, and technical services industries accounted for 14 percent of growth.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP grew 0.6 percent after growing 4.9 percent in the third quarter. Inventory investment turned down; exports, consumer spending, and federal government spending decelerated. Motor vehicle output turned down.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Preview of Revised NIPA Estimates for 2002: Effects of Incorporating the 2002 Benchmark I-O Accounts and Proposed Definition and Statistical Changes
row.Author: Kurt Kunze, Stephanie H. McCulla
row.Description: This article presents preliminary estimates of gross domestic product based on the newly available benchmark input-output accounts, which will be formally incorporated into the national accounts as part of next year's comprehensive revision.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: NIPA Translation of the Fiscal Year 2009 Federal Budget
row.Author: Benjamin A. Mandel, Andrew E. Vargo
row.Description: Every year, BEA prepares federal government estimates that are based on the proposed budget of the U.S. government. This analysis is often used to gauge the effects of the federal budget on U.S. economic activity.
row.Category: National, NIPA translation of the federal budget

row.Title: A Primer on BEA's Government Accounts
row.Author: Bruce E. Baker, Pamela A. Kelly
row.Description: Government activity is a key component of the economy. This article offers an introduction to BEA's government accountsâ€”their structure, concepts, and production.

row.Title: Foreign Location Choices by U.S. Multinational Companies
row.Author: Raymond J. Mataloni Jr.
row.Description: This article takes a look at the process by which U.S. multinational companies decide where to locate their investments abroad.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP grew 0.6 percent after growing 4.9 percent in the third quarter. Inventory investment turned down; exports, consumer spending, and federal government spending decelerated. Motor vehicle output turned down.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Fourth Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Debasis Chaudhuri
row.Description: Net government saving decreased $25.3 billion to â€“$268.5 billion. Net federal government saving increased $3.6 billion to â€“$226.7 billion. Net state and local government saving decreased $28.9 billion to â€“$41.9 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade for the Fourth Quarter of 2007
row.Description: These estimates, including estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: Fourth Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Elena L. Nguyen, Jessica Melton Hanson
row.Description: The current-account deficit decreased $4.5 billion to $172.9 billion as a result of increases in the surpluses on income and services. In the financial account, net financial inflows increased $119.0 billion to $230.1 billion.

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions in 2007
row.Author: Christopher L. Bach
row.Description: The current-account deficit decreased $72.8 billion to $738.6 billion as a result of increases in the surpluses on income and services and a decrease in the deficit on goods. In the financial account, net financial inflows decreased $175.8 billion to $657.4 billion.

row.Title: State Personal Income: Fourth Quarter of 2007 and Annual Estimates for 2007
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Fourth-quarter personal income growth ranged from 1.4 percent in South Dakota to 0.6 percent in Tennessee. For 2007, growth slowed in the Mideast, Southeast, Southwest, Rocky Mountain, and Far West regions and accelerated in the New England and Plains regions.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the First Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP grew 0.6 percent after growing 0.6 percent in the fourth quarter of 2007. Consumer spending for services, inventory investment, and exports increased. In contrast, housing investment and consumer spending for durable goods decreased.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Preview of the 2009 Comprehensive Revision of the National Income and Product Accounts: New Classifications for Personal Consumption Expenditures
row.Author: Clinton P. McCully, Teresita D. Teensma
row.Description: The new classification system for personal consumption expenditures defines new categories of expenditures by type of expenditure and type of product. In addition, the new system will make the national income and product accounts more consistent with international guidelines.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Returns for Domestic Nonfinancial Business
row.Author: Paul R. Lally, Andrew W. Hodge, Robert J. Corea
row.Description: BEA publishes aggregate rates of returns and Q ratios annually. In 2007, the profitability of nonfinancial corporations decreased for the third time since 2000.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Toward a Health Care Satellite Account
row.Author: Ana M. Aizcorbe, Bonnie A. Retus, Shelly Smith
row.Description: As the economic importance of health care spending grows, BEA plans to construct a satellite account for health care spending that would allow analysts to better assess the returns to treatments of disease and the sources of changes in health care costs.

row.Title: A Empirical Review of Methods for Temporal Distribution and Interpolation in the National Accounts
row.Author: Baoline Chen, Stephen H. Andrews
row.Description: This article summarizes research by BEA economists that assessed the relative strengths and weaknesses of various methods of interpolation used in economic accounting.

row.Title: Annual Industry Accounts: Advance Statistics on GDP by Industry for 2007
row.Author: Brian M. Lindberg, Justin M. Monaldo
row.Description: In 2007, slowing economic growth was mainly accounted for by four industry groupsâ€”finance and insurance, construction, real estate and rental and leasing, and mining. The finance and insurance industry group accounted for nearly half of the slowdown.

row.Title: Local Area Personal Income for 2006
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: County personal income growth in 2006 ranged from 648 percent in St. Bernard, Louisiana, to â€“43 percent in Slope, North Dakota. For the nation, personal income grew 6.7 percent.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the First Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 0.9 percent after increasing 0.6 percent in the fourth quarter. Consumer spending for services, exports, federal government spending, and inventory investment increased. In contrast, consumer spending for durable goods and housing investment decreased.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)
row.Supp1_Title: The Effect of the Economic Stimulus Act of 2008 on Corporate Profits

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: First Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Debasis Chaudhuri
row.Description: Net government saving decreased $115.3 billion to â€“$375.6 billion. Net federal government saving decreased $93.4 billion to â€“$311.9 billion. State and local government saving decreased $21.8 billion to â€“$63.7 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: U.S. Travel and Tourism Satellite Accounts for 2004â€“2007
row.Author: Sarah R. Mattingly, Eric S. Griffith
row.Description: The travel and tourism industry grew for the sixth consecutive year in 2007. Revised estimates show that the industry grew 1.9 percent in 2007, compared with 3.1 percent in 2006 and 2.9 percent in 2005.
row.Category: Industry, Travel and tourism satellite accounts

row.Title: Improving BEA's Accounts Through Flexible Annual Revisions
row.Author: Robert J. Kornfeld, Brian C. Moyer, George M. Smith, David F. Sullivan, Robert E. Yuskavage
row.Description: The Bureau of Economic Analysis will take a new approach to annual revisions of its economic accounts beginning in 2010. This article discusses the benefits of the new approach.

row.Title: Foreign Direct Investment in the United States: New Investment in 2007
row.Author: Y. Louise Ku-Graf
row.Description: Outlays by foreign investors to acquire or establish U.S. businesses increased $111.2 billion to $276.8 billion, the second largest outlays on record and the highest level since the peak in 2000.
row.Category: International, Foreign direct investment in the United States

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
row.Description: Real GDP increased 1.0 percent after increasing 0.6 percent in the fourth quarter. Consumer spending for services, exports, federal government spending, and inventory investment increased. In contrast, consumer spending for durable goods and housing investment decreased.

row.Title: GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the First Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: These estimates, including estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade for the First Quarter of 2008
row.Description: These estimates, including estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: The International Investment Position of the United States at Yearend 2007
row.Author: Elena L. Nguyen
row.Description: The net international investment position was â€“$2,441.8 billion; it was â€“$2,225.8 billion at yearend 2006. The change was mainly due to strong foreign acquisitions of U.S. financial assets.

row.Title: Direct Investment Positions for 2007: Country and Industry Detail
row.Author: Marilyn Ibarra, Jennifer Koncz
row.Description: The historical-cost positions of both U.S. direct investment abroad and foreign direct investment in the United States increased 14 percent. In 2006, U.S. direct investment abroad increased 10 percent, and foreign direct investment in the United States increased 13 percent.
row.Category: International, Direct investment positions: Country and industry detail

row.Title: Annual Revision of the U.S. International Accounts, 1974â€“2007
row.Author: Christopher L. Bach
row.Description: Once a year, U.S. transactions and international investment position statistics are revised to incorporate updated data and various statistical improvements. The main improvements this year were in services and securities.

row.Title: How BEA Aligns and Augments Source Data From the U.S. Treasury Department for Inclusion in the International Transactions Accounts
row.Description: Once a year, estimates of financial-account flows in the international transactions accounts, which are based on Treasury Department data, are adjusted to align the estimates with balance-of-payments concepts and to close gaps in coverage.

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: First Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Renee M. Sauers, Kristy L. Howell
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit increased $9.1 billion to $176.4 billion, mainly reflecting a decrease in the surplus on income. In the financial account, net financial inflows decreased $89.1 billion to $124.3 billion.

row.Title: Gross Domestic Product by State: Advance Estimates for 2007 and Revised Estimates for 2004â€“2006
row.Author: John E. Broda, Caitlin E. Coakley
row.Description: Economic growth slowed in 36 states in 2007. Contractions in construction and in finance and insurance restrained growth in many states.
row.Category: Regional, Gross domestic product by state

row.Title: State Personal Income: First Quarter of 2008
row.Description: Growth ranged from 7.6 percent in North Dakota to â€“1.9 percent in Arkansas. Nationally, personal income grew 1.1 percent, compared with 1.2 percent in the fourth quarter.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 1.9 percent after increasing 0.9 percent in the first quarter. Prices of goods and services purchased by U.S. residents rose 4.2 percent after rising 3.5 percent, reflecting accelerating energy and food prices.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Annual Revision of the National Income and Product Accounts: Annual Estimates for 2005â€“2007 and Quarterly Estimates for the First Quarter of 2005 to the First Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Eugene P. Seskin, Shelly Smith
row.Description: Annual revisions update the accounts by incorporating new data and various methodological improvements. From 2004 to 2007, real GDP growth was revised to 2.6 percent from 2.7 percent. This annual revision did not change the general picture of the economy over the past few years.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: National Income and Product Accounts Tables
row.Description: The revised annual, quarterly, and monthly statistics from the annual NIPA revision, including advance estimates for the second quarter of 2008 and June 2008.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: GDP and Other Major NIPA Series for 1929â€“the Second Quarter of 2008
row.Description: Historical statistics of GDP and its components in current dollars, chained dollars, and chain-type quantity and price indexes, including statistics on national income and personal income.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: U.S. Affiliates of Foreign Companies: Operations in 2006
row.Author: Thomas Anderson
row.Description: Growth in current-dollar value added of U.S. affiliates picked up in 2006, as existing affiliate operations expanded. Employment by affiliates also picked up.
row.Category: International, Foreign direct investment in the United States

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 3.3 percent after increasing 0.9 percent in the first quarter. Prices paid by U.S. residents rose 4.2 percent after rising 3.5 percent, reflecting accelerating energy and food prices.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Second Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Karla L. Stanley-Allen
row.Description: Net government saving decreased $329.4 billion to â€“$712.5 billion. Net federal government saving decreased $305.5 billion to â€“$636.2 billion. Net state and local government saving decreased $23.9 billion to â€“$76.3 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Tables
row.Description: As part of the annual NIPA revision, statistics on government spending by function, changes in the net stock of produced assets, and a comparison of NIPA and USDA net farm income are presented.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Fixed Assets and Consumer Durable Goods for 1998â€“2007
row.Author: David Wasshausen
row.Description: Statistics on (1) the net stock of equipment and software and of business and government structures and (2) the net stock of consumer durable goods. Both reflect the annual NIPA revision.
row.Category: National, Fixed assets and consumer durable goods

row.Title: Direct Investment, 2004â€“2007: Detailed Historical-Cost Positions and Related Capital and Income Flows
row.Author: Jeffrey H. Lowe
row.Description: Statistics on (1) the direct investment positions and international transactions of U.S and foreign multinational companies and (2) the composition of investment by U.S. companies abroad and foreign companies in the United States.
row.Supp2_Title: Foreign Direct Investment in the United States Tables

row.Title: Personal Income for Metropolitan Areas for 2007
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income growth slowed in 208 of the nation's 363 metropolitan areas. Growth in metropolitan areas averaged 6.0 percent, down from 6.5 percent in 2006.
row.Category: Regional, Personal income for metropolitan areas

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 2.8 percent after increasing 0.9 percent in the first quarter. Prices paid by U.S. residents rose 4.2 percent after rising 3.5 percent, reflecting accelerating energy and food prices.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Tables
row.Description: Statistics on federal receipts and expenditures and the federal budget, state and local government receipts and expenditures and Census Bureau data, state and local government receipts and expenditures, and seasonally unadjusted estimates.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade
row.Description: These estimates for the fourth quarter of 2004 through the second quarter of 2008 reflect the most recent annual revision of the national income and product accounts.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: U.S. International Services: Cross-Border Trade in 2007 and Services Supplied Through Affiliates in 2006
row.Author: Jennifer Koncz, Anne Flatness
row.Description: A broad look at U.S. international services, including both cross-border trade and services supplied through affiliates. This year's article includes several improvements to these statistics.

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions for the Second Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Mai-Chi Hoang, Erin M. Whitaker
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit increased $7.5 billion to $183.1 billion. In the financial account, net financial inflows decreased $53.6 billion to $136.7 billion.

row.Title: Gross Domestic Product by Metropolitan Area: Newly Available Statistics for 2006 and Revised Statistics for 2004â€“2005
row.Author: Christian E. MalagÃ³n, Timothy P. McInerney, Sharon D. Panek
row.Description: Economic growth was widespread across metropolitan areas in 2006. Real GDP increased in 308 of 363 metropolitan areas. In 177 areas, GDP growth accelerated.
row.Category: Regional, Gross domestic product by metropolitan area

row.Title: State Personal Income for the Second Quarter of 2008 and Revised Statistics for 2005â€“2007
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income accelerated in the second quarter, rising 1.8 percent after rising 0.8 percent in the first quarter. The rise reflected tax rebate payments from the Economic Stimulus Act of 2008.

row.Title: BEA Regional Program Outreach in 2009
row.Description: BEA's regional economic accounts provide detailed estimates for states, counties, and metropolitan areas. To help users better understand and use these statistics, BEA participates in various conferences and workshops.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP decreased 0.3 percent after increasing 2.8 percent in the second quarter. Prices paid by U.S. residents increased 4.8 percent after increasing 4.2 percent, reflecting accelerating food prices.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Tables
row.Description: From the annual NIPA revision: statistics on personal income by households and nonprofit institutions serving households and a comparison of BEA and IRS statistics on nonprofits.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Updated Summary of NIPA Methodologies
row.Description: The source data and methods used to prepare current-dollar and real estimates of GDP and current-dollar estimates of gross domestic income have been updated as part of the annual NIPA revision.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: U.S. Multinational Companies: Operations in 2006
row.Author: Raymond J. Mataloni Jr.
row.Description: The value added of U.S. multinational companies increased 8.4 percent. The value added of U.S. parents increased 8.1 percent, and the value of their foreign affiliates increased 9.2 percent.

row.Title: Reconciliation of the United Statesâ€“Canadian Current Account, 2006 and 2007
row.Author: Renee Sauers, Edward Dozier, Denis Caron
row.Description: Each year, the bilateral current-account estimates of the United States and Canada are reconciled to show how the estimates would appear if both countries used the same definitions, methodologies, and data sources.

row.Title: Regional Price Parities: Comparing Price Level Differences Across Geographic Areas
row.Author: Bettina H. Aten, Roger J. D'Souza
row.Description: A look at BEA's research into regional price parities, which show price level differences across various regions in the United States. These parities are used to adjust regional personal income and GDP measures for 2005 and 2006.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP decreased 0.5 percent after increasing 2.8 percent in the second quarter. Prices paid by U.S. residents increased 4.7 percent after increasing 4.2 percent, reflecting accelerating food prices.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures for the Third Quarter of 2008
row.Author: Karla L. Stanley-Allen
row.Description: Net government saving increased $71.4 billion to â€“$645.0 billion. Net federal government saving increased $106.4 billion to â€“$543.2 billion. Net state and local government saving decreased $34.9 billion to â€“$101.8 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Gross Domestic Income: Revisions and Source Data
row.Author: Alyssa E. Holdren, Bruce T. Grimm
row.Description: As a measure of the U.S. economy, gross domestic income (GDI) complements gross domestic product. In this article, we explain the source data used to calculate the earliest GDI statistics.

row.Title: Annual Industry Accounts: Revised Statistics for 2005â€“2007
row.Author: Soo jeong Kim, Vincent A. Davis, Anna M. Jacobson, Amanda S. Lyndaker
row.Description: In 2007, the slowdown in U.S. economic growth was widespread among industries. Professional and business services and "real estate and rental and leasing" accounted for about half of the growth. Construction subtracted from economic growth for the first time since 2001.
row.Supp2_Title: Imports as a Share of Domestic Supply

row.Title: Subject Guide for 2008
row.Description: This guide lists the articles that were published in the Survey in 2008.

row.Title: Schedule of BEA News Releases in 2009
